content.webTitle: From the archive: health and wellbeing advice from 1975

fields.headline: From the archive: health and wellbeing advice from 1975
fields.bodyText: The Observer Magazine issue of 12 January 1975 had a host of articles relating to health and wellbeing (‘Are you energetic enough? The science of get-up-and-go’), which included some dietary case studies. It’s not all that surprising to hear the infamously energetic Margaret Thatcher, then 49, say: ‘You could say I eat to live rather than live to eat.’ She reveals that she always has half a grapefruit and a boiled egg for breakfast, which was probably all she felt like after four hours’ sleep. Barbara Cartland, 73, claims that she took 90 vitamin pills a day, which seems scarcely more credible than one of her own plots. But then again, she did live to 98. Yehudi Menuhin, 58, who also made it to a very ripe old age (83), tells us that he ate vegetables cooked in milk, but sadly not why. In ‘The secrets of human energy’, Richard Fisher writes about the importance of the mind as well as the body. ‘The powerhouse may survive on hamburgers and coffee, but it is his psychological state that carries him forward.’ Another feature asked, ‘Is yours the right lunch to keep you going?’ highlighting such staples as the ‘pub lunch’, defined as a ‘steak pie, baked beans and half a pint of shandy. This will keep you going for 5 hours 50 minutes’ and a ‘snack lunch’ of a doughnut and a cup of coffee, which ‘will keep you going satisfactorily for 3 hours 20 minutes.’ These are my kind of energy recommendations. Included in a list of do’s and don’ts is this gem: ‘Don’t take tonics. Many of them contain alcohol or opium. Stout may be a safe pick-me-up and it is still relatively cheap, but opium in any form is dangerous.’ If only Renton in Trainspotting had heeded these words and replaced his opium suppositories with a half of stout.
